The ABCs of HTML
Parts of the Code 

Parts of the Code

Every Michigan Virtual HTML template will have a header.* The header contains a link to the Cascading Style Sheet (CSS), which defines styles for the elements in an HTML document. The JavaScript code will add interactivity and other dynamic functionality to the page.

This will include the styles.css and script.js files in the HTML document. It is important to note that JavaScript code for the Michigan Virtual templates should always be placed at the bottom of the body. The following information will be useful to know and explored further in other courses.

This is a figure caption for this image.

The image below shows the project example with all of the assets you will be using located and labeled. Refer back to the "Step 1" image- remember that all of the assets shown in this example project image will go in the blue highlighted section between the Header and Closing Tags mentioned in the "Step 1 image."


*Please Note: Do not delete the head content. The head content for the D2L Brightspace templates needs to be kept. While we recommend you explore your creativity and freedom with the content and styles inside of the <body> tags, it is recommended that you do not make any changes within the<head> tags. This is where the information, such as the links to the CSS and JavaScript files, that power the interactivity and visual aesthetics of the page live. If these links were to change or be removed, the page would not be displayed as expected.
